NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 学会，学院，研究院
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. If you want to be a musician, you go to the Royal Academy of Music.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a person or thing added 增加的人（或物）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The baby is a welcome addition to the Smith family.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. one of two or more possibilities 供选择的东西
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Check out the alternatives before deciding whether to go to a nearby college.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 天使
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She is in heaven with the angels.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 盎格鲁-萨克逊人
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Anglo-Saxons did not have a letter V.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. provoke (a particular feeling or attitude) 唤起，激起
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. These educational toys give children a feeling of self-worth by arousing their interest in challenging tasks.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  forbid (sth.) officially 禁止，取缔
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The local government will ban smoking in all offices later this year.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 密封小容器；胶囊；航天舱
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The space capsule had three astronauts.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a sudden great disaster 大灾难
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The flood was a major catastrophe, causing heavy loss of life.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 凯尔特人
n. 海峡，渠道，频道
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The English Channel separates Britain from France.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 基督教  Christian a. 基督教的  n. 基督教徒
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Most of my friends believe in Christianity.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a work of art recognized as having lasting value 经典作品
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His manual on botany has become a classic among scientists.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (an area or a region with) a regular pattern of weather conditions 气候（区）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Brought up in the south of China, she wouldn't enjoy living in such a cold climate.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v.  take possession and control by force; defeat 征服
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Afghanistan's Northern Alliance conquered Kabul a month ago.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. cause errors to appear in; cause to act dishonestly in return for personal gains 讹用，使（语言）变得不标准；腐蚀，贿赂
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Academy ruled that such foreign expressions were not permitted as they corrupted the language.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  of or involving culture 文化的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Foundation（基金）promotes cultural and educational exchanges between China and Britain.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  the notional environment in which communication over computer networks occurs 网络空间，虚拟空间
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In computer technology, cyberspace refers to databanks and networks, considered as a space.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 丹麦（人）的，丹麦语的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was the son of a Danish father and a Venezuelan mother.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. come down (from a source), go down 起源于，下来
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. These ideas descend from those of the ancient philosophers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 信徒，门徒
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. one of the disciples of Christ

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. move or go somewhere in a slow casual way 漂泊
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Jimmy spent the year drifting around Europe.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the group regarded as the best （总称）出类拔萃的人，精英
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The army was controlled by a small elite of officers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. make rich or richer; improve 使富裕，使丰富
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. That once poor coastal village has been enriched by the profits from tourism.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. cause to be, set up 建立，确立
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The school was established in 1905 by an Italian professor.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. of great interest or attraction 迷人的，有极大吸引力的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The story of his adventures in the Arctic was fascinating to listen to.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad.  by good luck 幸运地，幸亏
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Fortunately, my friend survived the car accident.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 日耳曼（人）的，日耳曼语的，德国（人）的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He asked in his Germanic English if I was enjoying the visit.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 语法学家
n. 希腊语
a. done as a habit, regular, usual 惯常的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She was a habitual daydreamer.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 印欧语系的
n. 影响
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Parents have greatest influence on their children.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  live in (a place) 居住于
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. This island is inhabited only by birds.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n., a. 知识分子（的）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The book does not appeal to real intellectuals.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. enter with armed forces 侵入，侵略
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Germans invaded Poland in 1939, leading to the start of World War II.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. 发明  invention n.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. James Watt invented the steam engine.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 国王（般）的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Waving his arms in a kingly manner, he led his company back to the royal dwellings.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  拉丁语
n. freedom 自由
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The constitution guards the liberty of the people.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a person who studies languages 语言学家
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He is an accomplished linguist.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 制造商
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The company is the world's largest doll manufacturer.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 殉难者，烈士
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He is a glorious martyr to the cause of peace.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. large in scale, amount, or degree 大量的，大规模的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The ancient temple's massive stone pillars had begun to crumble.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 杂乱状况  messy a.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. As the work is in messiness you'll need to wear old clothes.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. change slightly 修改，更改
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The school authorities plan to modify the school regulations.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 神秘的事物
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The politician's sudden death remains a mystery to us all.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 必需品；必要（性）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A lot of people would consider a TV as more of a necessity than a luxury item.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.,a. 诺曼人(的), 诺曼语(的), 诺曼文化的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In Norman England, the greyhound was a symbol of nobility.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.（古）斯堪的纳维亚语
滋养，培育
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Journalists on the whole don't create public opinion. They can help to nourish it.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 失去控制，不受约束
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The fire was out of control by the time the second fire engine arrived.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 游行；阅兵队列  hit parade a weekly listing of the current best-selling pop records 流行唱片目录
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The small boys loved watching the soldiers on parade.

NewWords.WordPhrase: hand or give (sth.) to (sb.) 将…传给…
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. When you have finished reading the novel, please pass it on to Laura.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 独占的地区或范围；禁猎地  vt. keep from harm, damage, etc., protect; save 保护，保存
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. No hunting allowed in this preserve.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 产品
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They go to the market to buy supplies and sell their products.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 将…付诸实施
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Having delayed several times, we must put this plan into practice now.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  （欧洲14-16世纪的）文艺复兴
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Science took a new and different turn in the Renaissance.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. be like or similar to 与…相似
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I'd say he resembles his mother more that his father.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 古罗马的，拉丁语的
a. 国王或女王的；皇家的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The newborn baby was welcomed not only by the Japanese royal family but by the country at large.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  梵语
n. 学者
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The library attracts thousands of scholars and researchers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a small meal 快餐，点心  snack bar 快餐柜，小吃店
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I usually have a snack of a hamburger and a glass of coke at lunchtime.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  源，来源
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Tourism, which is a major source for income for the city, has been seriously affected by the terrorist attacks.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (of power) without limit, highest;(of a nation) fully independent 拥有最高统治权的，至高无上的；拥有主权的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Russian Federation declared itself to be a sovereign republic.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 严格地讲
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Strictly speaking, it is not one house at all, but three houses joined together.

NewWords.WordPhrase: create, produce 创造，开创
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. After working for his father for about ten years, he decided to strike out on his own.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. give in 投降
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They would rather die than surrender.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  done according to a system 有系统的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The police began a systematic search of the building.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  温度计
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A thermometer is an instrument for measuring temperature.

NewWords.Word: to a (very real, certain, etc.) extent
NewWords.WordPhrase: to the degree specified 在（极大，某种）程度上
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I agree with him to some extent, but there are still some areas of sharp disagreement between us.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 容忍，宽容；忍耐
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. School teachers have to have a great deal of tolerance in order to deal with difficult children.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 译本，译文；翻译
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Hundreds of translations of the Bible have been prepared.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  部落
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The tribe held religious ceremonies next to a river.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.,a.  录像（的）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Video has been made wide use of for teaching.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad.  for the most part, almost 差不多，几乎
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It's virtually impossible to tell the imitation from the real thing.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  词汇（量）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He has an English vocabulary of about 5,000 words.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a small cassette player 随身听
a.,n. 威尔士语（的），威尔士人（的）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Welsh eat more potatoes than anyone else.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  狼
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A wolf is a wild animal that looks like a large dog.
